page.title: 17LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Recollections of a Man of 76 years, December 1963-One of the first recollections is the blizzard of 1891, when the snow in the road from Cargreen to Cross was level with the tops of the hedges. Transport in those days and up to 1914 was by horse and trap or four-wheeled carriages. Public transport was mainly on the river where the old Saltash Steamboat Co. ran a market steamer from Calstock to North Corner, Devonport, three days a week.The fare was one shilling return. The ferry was the next best way of getting to Plymouth on days when the steamers were not running, crossing the river by boat and then across the fields to Bere Ferrers station, and going by train.Practically everything in the way of goods were brought by way of the River Tamar,even coal came by two-masted schooner.
